output.conclusion: By completing this course, you will have a strong foundation in causal inference methods, enabling you to critically evaluate research and design your own causal studies.
output.introduction: This advanced course delves into the complexities of causal inference, equipping you with the tools to move beyond correlation and uncover true causal relationships. We will explore various methods, assumptions, and challenges in identifying and estimating causal effects.

chapters.description: Introduction to the potential outcomes framework, also known as the Rubin Causal Model. Defining causal effects using potential outcomes. The fundamental problem of causal inference.
Discussing key assumptions: ignorability/exchangeability, positivity/overlap, and consistency. Understanding the implications of violating these assumptions.
Overview of different strategies for identifying causal effects: randomization, conditioning, instrumental variables, regression discontinuity, and difference-in-differences.
Review of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) as the gold standard for causal inference. Advantages and limitations of RCTs. Practical considerations in designing and analyzing RCTs.
Challenges of causal inference in observational studies. Confounding and selection bias. Strategies for addressing confounding: matching, stratification, and weighting.
Introduction to propensity scores. Propensity score matching, weighting, and stratification. Assessing balance after propensity score adjustment.

modules.moduleTitle: Causal Inference in Experimental and Observational Settings

chapters.description: Introduction to instrumental variables. Conditions for a valid instrument: relevance, exclusion restriction, and independence. Two-stage least squares (2SLS) estimation.
Sharp and fuzzy regression discontinuity designs. Identifying causal effects at the threshold. Assumptions and limitations of RD.
The difference-in-differences approach for estimating causal effects. Parallel trends assumption. Extensions of DID: multiple groups and time periods.
Understanding mediation pathways. Direct and indirect effects. Causal mediation analysis using potential outcomes.
Examining effect modification and causal interactions. Identifying and estimating heterogeneous treatment effects.
Challenges of causal inference with time-varying treatments and confounders. Marginal structural models (MSMs) and g-estimation.
Assessing the robustness of causal inferences to unmeasured confounding. Sensitivity analysis techniques for different causal methods.
Introduction to causal discovery algorithms. Learning causal structures from observational data. Limitations of causal discovery methods.
Integrating causal inference with machine learning. Using machine learning for causal effect estimation. Causal machine learning algorithms.
